This platform is also open to other partners interesting in sharing geo-referenced information on natural features and human activities and their pressures and impacts on nature and ecosystems, as well as conservation and protection actions undertaken or proposed in the Mediterranean region.
The geo-referenced maps (GIS files) are available for download, and also displayed to be harvested by other geoportals as long as the source is cited. Explore, discover relevant data and share it!!

elements.value: The first ever European Red List of Habitats recently published the current status of all terrestrial, freshwater and marine habitats and highlights the pressures they face.

From 2013-2016, the European Red List of Habitats examined the extent and status of all the benthic marine habitats in the different European Seas including the Mediterranean. Among these habitats are the coralligenous, one of the most important ecosystems in the Mediterranean Sea.
Pie foto: Coralligenous habitats are often called “gardens or forests”. But they are not made of corals!!

They are hard bottom habitats made by the accumulation of calcareous encrusting algae growing and shaping these structures where a rich associated fauna flourish in poor light conditions. From here, the term commonly used when refer to them as “bioconcretions”. Their shape, depends on the depth, topography, and the nature of the algal builders that ultimately will develop banks or rim constructions in vertical cliffs or rocky outcrops.

These colourful landscapes can be found growing on a variety of locations and at depths ranging from 20 to 200 meters. They are also known to be one of the most important habitats in the Mediterranean because they can offer shelter and subsistence for many forms of marine life, and are considered important for fisheries and carbon cycling.
On shallow waters, the infralittoral zone, coralligenous concretions always develop in almost vertical walls, deep channels, or overhangs, and occupy small areas.

credit.footer: Mediterranean gorgonean forest.

elements.value: From the shallow waters to almost 70m depth, these biogenic constructions rich on marine life seem to be decreasing in quality and quantity.

What is certain from what is known is that this habitat is mostly being degraded and threatened by pollution (e.g. wastewater discharge from the coast) and various bottom fishing techniques and gears that increase the re-suspension of nearby sediments and affect the abundance of keystone species. The spread of exotic algae, Climate change (increasing and unusual fluctuations of seawater temperature) and frequency of storms are also known to affect several key species that are part of coralligenous habitats.

credit.footer: European Red List of Habitats, EIONET

elements.value: The designation of Marine Protected Areas and specific measures to improve water quality and limit fishing trawling activities should help protect these submarine gardens. Further, a better design and enforcement of management activities, particularly  for traditional and recreational fisheries, can prevent stock depletion of target fish and crustaceans through new quotas, control of users and surveillance and compliance of regulations.

info.title: Infralittoral biogenic habitats in the Mediterranean - corralligenous bioconcretions

elements.value: Coralligenous habitats are reported to occur primarily in the northern part of the Mediterranean basin, with few records from the eastern or southern basin. Many coralligenous habitats have already been affected by various stressors such as an increase of nutrients from inland and maritime activities, overexploitation, invasive species, increasing sedimentation, and mechanical impacts which, added to the influence of climate change, is resulting in serious consequences for many species and for the structure of the whole habitat.

Some of the characteristic species found in this habitat are Rhodophyta (red algae), Phaeophyta (Brown algae), Chlorophyta (green algae), sponges, bryozoans, crustaceans, polychaetes, molluscs, tunicates and many different fishes. All these types of species use coralligenous habitats at some stage. in their lives: for breeding, feeding and nourishment; sheltering the growth of biodiversity in their waters. Taking into consideration the decline observed in habitat extent and quality, coralligenous habitats are classified as Near Threatened in Mediterranean European waters. Hence that measures such as further data collection and monitoring, new regulations and the protection of important areas are being promoted.

There is a clear lack of data for coralligenous habitats in the south and east of the Mediterranean. Coralligenous outcrops are reported to occur primarily in the northern part of the Mediterranean basin, with few records from the eastern or southern basin. Nonetheless, there is very limited knowledge from the east and south Mediterranean.

The Mediterranean Sea is one of the most important tourist destinations in the world. The benign climate, gastronomic variety and various cultures inhabiting the area attract millions of visitors each year. Its peoples, living in more than 20 countries, largely depend on the sea, as it provides them with food resources, fantastic beaches, cleaner air, jobs and a millennial connection for transport and travel among other.

However, what keeps the sea alive is not always on view: marine habitats like coralligenous in this case, are essential for the survival of many and varied marine species, but also for the people’s livelihoods. It is therefore critical to protect and promote a healthy marine environment for them to maintain the Mediterranean as we know it today.

Taking into account the impacts that coralligenous habitats have today as well as other future pressures brought by climate change, the decline in habitat extent and quality make them to be classified as Near Threatened for Europe. An important feature of this habitat to be considered also is that in the Mediterranean, up to 48% of the algae species living in them are endemics.
To reverse this trend, we need to join forces in a concerted effort to protect their locations against pollution, malfishing practices and the spread of invasive species among others.
Because our marine gardens and forests take a long time to grow, but very little to be destroyed…

In temperate sea like the Mediterranean, diving is one the main attractions for people eager to visit colourful submarine gardens. Coralline constructions are considered hotspots of biodiversity and are extremely popular among divers.
The coralligenous includes several fauna and flora assemblages due to its high heterogeneity. Algal asemblages develop in open waters and are dominated by several species of encrusting red algae

Here, mixed with algae, mainly gorgonians dominate the assemblage in nutrient rich areas, and in more poor waters sponges and bryozoans dominate. In overhangs and big cavities the communities of suspension feeders are dominated by different anthozoans, sponges and bryozoans. Coralligenous formations with species like the gorgonians Paramuricea clavata, Eunicella verrucosa and the orange coral Astroides calycularis, and of course the precious Corallium rubrum, are Mediterranean treasures that form part of our heritage

Indeed, it is worth considering that that some of these ecosystems are estimated to take several thousand years to be built, as in the case of the constructions of Lithophylum algae, which constitute real natural monuments.
Raising awareness on the importance of a harmless diving behaviour can reduce the trend towards degradation of these habitats, and assist to better monitor and conserve them for the future.

elements.value: Butterflies provide a wide range of environmental benefits. In addition to their role as pollinators and food for others, some have even developed their own ways to deter predators and parasites, find a mate, or overcome the chemical defences of their host plant. Each of these butterfly chemicals has a potential value and could be exploited economically. Powerful antibiotics for example have been found in the Meadow Brown (Maniola jurtina), one common and widespread species.

The last 50 years have however seen a massive change in agricultural practices across the Mediterranean, with a loss of wildlife-rich habitats by increasing urbanization and tourism infrastructure. The growing chronic water shortages are also having a major socio-economic impact on large parts of the region, as many small-scale farmers feel forced to abandon their land to search for jobs elsewhere. Land abandonment leads to former grassland getting overgrown with shrubs, turning into secondary forests and therefore reducing suitable habitats for many butterfly species. Overgrazing can reduce the availability of nutritious plants and refuge for larvae too. These changes are leading to the disappearance of some of these colourful and unique creatures.
Butterflies and moths belong to the order Lepidoptera. Lepidos is Greek for  "scales" and ptera means "wings". Their scaly wings are different from those of any other insects.

Scales play an important part in their natural history. They enable the development of vivid or indistinct patterns to help them conceal, camouflage, for mimicry and for warning potential predators. Besides providing insulation, dark patterns on wings help absorb the sunlight and assist in regulating the body temperature. Bright and distinctive colour patterns in butterflies help communicate their toxicity or inedibility to prevent a predator from preying on it.
Scales are also present on the thorax and other parts of the butterfly to  contribute to maintaining the high body temperatures required during flight.

elements.value: The IUCN Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation is evaluating the state of conservation of a selection of taxonomic groups in the Mediterranean region. There are 463 butterflies native to the Mediterranean and the assessment recently published by IUCN reveals that 19 butterfly species are threatened with extinction, among which 15 endemic species.

credit.footer: Resource: IUCN, Centre for Mediterranean Cooperation.

elements.value: There is still an information gap on the geographic distribution of butterflies, the size and the reproduction trends of their populations, mostly for species south and east of the Mediterranean. Beyond further data collection and monitoring, a review of legislation affecting their protection and action plans for particular species and habitats are the main recommendations from experts to encourage the preservation of these winged creatures in the Mediterranean landscape.

elements.value: Butterflies and moths belong to the order Lepidoptera. Lepidos is Greek for  "scales" and ptera means "wings". Their scaly wings are different from those of any other insects.

Scales play an important part in their natural history. They enable the development of vivid or indistinct patterns to help them conceal, camouflage, for mimicry and for warning potential predators. Besides providing insulation, dark patterns on wings help absorb the sunlight and assist in regulating the body temperature. Bright and distinctive colour patterns in butterflies help communicate their toxicity or inedibility to prevent a predator from preying on it.
Scales are also present on the thorax and other parts of the butterfly to  contribute to maintaining the high body temperatures required during flight.
Butterflies are considered good indicators for the state of the environment and due to their short cycle, narrow niches and relatively low mobility, they are very sensitive to land-use changes.

Despite the percentage of threatened butterflies being lower than in other groups in the region, there is a lack of information on the distribution, population size and trends for several species, which could mean an increased number of threatened species. Agricultural intensification, overgrazing and land abandonment are a threat to Mediterranean butterfly diversity.

At present there are 22 countries where butterflies are monitored. However, most of them are not situated in the Mediterranean region, with the exception of Spain and France. There is therefore a need to increase data collection and monitoring on the southern and eastern shores of the Mediterranean, where many endemic species inhabit, as a first step to ensure their protection through better legislation and concrete action plans.

Butterflies have been for a long time a symbol for transformation and evolution. One also talks about the "butterfly effect" when small causes can have large effects.  Indeed, despite their small size, butterflies are key pieces in the Mediterranean landscape. They participate in the essential ecosystems functioning as pollinators and as prey for other species during their different life cycles. Aesthetic and cultural values are also associated to their presence in the region, adding colour and beauty to Mediterranean mountains, grasslands and landscapes.
Agricultural intensification, overgrazing and land abandonment are a threat to Mediterranean butterfly diversity. Forest fires and climate change are also risks to their survival.

Conservation actions necessary for their protection are the review of national and international legislation to include threatened species, and the device of species/habitat action plans where most needed. Field work and data monitoring for Data Deficient species, with strong regional cooperation as the basis, are also needed all along the Mediterranean.
a flower knows, when its butterfly will return, and if the moon walks out, the sky will understand; but now it hurts, to watch you leave so soon,when I don't know, if you will ever come back.
The highest diversity of butterflies is found in mountainous areas in southern Turkey, northern Greece and southern France.

79% of threatened species are endemic. Such is the case of  the Karpathos Grayling (Hipparchia christenseni) which is found on rocky slopes covered with open scrub and in clearings in coniferous woods, where the butterflies often rest on the trunks of trees. This species occurs only on the Greek island of Karpathos.

79% of threatened species are endemic. Such is the case of  the Karpathos Grayling (Hipparchia christenseni) which is found on rocky slopes covered with open scrub and in clearings in coniferous woods, where the butterflies often rest on the trunks of trees. This species occurs only on the Greek island of Karpathos.

elements.value: Butterflies provide a wide range of environmental benefits. In addition to their role as pollinators and food for others, some have even developed their own ways to deter predators and parasites, find a mate, or overcome the chemical defences of their host plant. Each of these butterfly chemicals has a potential value and could be exploited economically. Powerful antibiotics for example have been found in the Meadow Brown (Maniola jurtina), one common and widespread species.

The last 50 years have however seen a massive change in agricultural practices across the Mediterranean, with a loss of wildlife-rich habitats by increasing urbanization and tourism infrastructure. The growing chronic water shortages are also having a major socio-economic impact on large parts of the region, as many small-scale farmers feel forced to abandon their land to search for jobs elsewhere. Land abandonment leads to former grassland getting overgrown with shrubs, turning into secondary forests and therefore reducing suitable habitats for many butterfly species. Overgrazing can reduce the availability of nutritious plants and refuge for larvae too. These changes are leading to the disappearance of some of these colourful and unique creatures.

Scales are also present on the thorax and other parts of the butterfly to  contribute to maintaining the high body temperatures required during flight.
